children.subject: Till now, I’ve taken about 3~4 techs a semester. Would 127 be easier than 126?

What combo of techs? 127 might be a little bit easier, but the homeworks are still going to be long and hard.

I think that unless you are a genius, 61c+170+126/127 will be nigh impossible and if maybe you are a genius but not a super super genius, you probably won't have time to do anything besides study all day.

(disclaimer: I haven't taken 126 or 127 but this seems to be what other people say + taking a brief glance over their homeworks, which is why I didn't post in the student response.)
I'm not OP, but I am considering taking 188 + 170 + 61C next sem, how does the workload compare to 61B + 70 + 16A (with Hilfinger, Sahai, Courtade)?

@Mouse 2 - I haven't taken 188, but I'd say those two courseloads sound pretty similar - 170 is comparable to 70, and from what I've heard 188 is a little easier than 61B with Hilfinger (think more like 61A, though some have told me that it's an underrated class in terms of workload). 61C may feel like a little more work than 16A just because your workload is mostly lumped into 3 projects and shorter homeworks throughout the semester instead of being distributed throughout weekly, somewhat lengthy problem sets like in 16A, but the lab component of each is comparable. Sounds like a pretty solid schedule to me!
So how does it compare to taking EE 127, CS 162, and CS 188 in my sophomore Spring?

That's going to be very very hard for most students. 61c+170 is already a pretty difficult combo (61c has long projects and 170 has long psets), and then adding on 126, which most people see has the hardest EECS course has even longer psets.

I guess what courseloads have you taken in the past and how did you feel about them?

If you take only those 3 (no other breadths/classes/clubs) then it may be possible, but seems like a lot of work. I personally try to avoid stacking pset classes, so 126/7 + 170 seems like a lot. Maybe consider a different class(ex. 188) + 61c + 170
Thank you so much for your response, I didn’t know that 61C was that intense. (Prof Garcia is teaching it next semester.)

I heard Garcia's iteration of 61C is quite manageable. Maybe that's just my experience but I found 61C to be a huge leap from 61B. Either way, you are the only one who knows what you are capable of. If you feel like you can manage all three, then, by all means, go for it.
What OP described seems to be pretty in line with Garcia's 61C. This semester, Weaver has changed his version to match Garcia's version in terms of workload too btw.
I can second this. Weaver has reduced the workload and added a clobber to make it in line with Garcia's version this semester (am in it)

I took Garcia's section and people seem to think that means it's easy but it isn't. I haven't taken Weaver's version, but he's apparently lowered the workload, and if Garcia's version is the workload bar then it's still a pretty high bar. I took 61C with 170 as my only two CS courses and it was really hard to manage, and I certainly did much worse than I normally do with other techs in a normal semester. I also took the fall ’19 iteration and since people were all working really hard and getting all the assignments done, the average course grade was high so the instructors made the final exam unusually difficult to (successfully) lower the average grade from an A- to a C/C+, which then then had to raise when doing final grade calculations. This isn't really necessary information for you but I just want to illustrate that no matter which section you take it will be tough and you might not be able to predict what you're gonna get in the course since they tell you over and over they won't curve it (as in 61A/B) but then they actually do find a way to scramble grades last-minute.

OP, I would only consider taking two of those classes but not all three. 61C and 170 are enough to keep your brain pretty much occupied all week. In fact, 61C alone is basically like taking 6 units and the workload itself is much more than that of most CS upper-divs. A typical week in CS61C goes something like this for your reference:
             - You have a two-hour lab (every week) but guess what, it mostly ends up taking much longer than that. 61C labs are brutal in my opinion.
             - You have homework due at the end of the week. Consider this to be a week-long problem set where you have to actually understand the nitty-gritty 
                details of the week's content to successfully finish the homework and get full credit.
             - Two lectures that go at lightening speed (this is not even funny). The amount of content in one single lecture is incredibly too much and in order to 
               do well, you need to understand almost everything in the slides because every piece of detail in this class is super important. 
             - Two discussions which you might actually be forced to attend since you realized that you barely absorbed content from the fast-paced lectures.
Then you have the projects. 61C projects are not as straight forward as those in 61A and 61B. You actually have to fully understand the material to do the projects and depending on who is teaching it, you might end up having not 3, not 4, but 5 projects. 
Unless you know the material beforehand, I would strongly advise against taking all three in one semester. You are a sophomore and therefore have so much time to take all the classes you would ever want. Take it easy.

I agree with this - you'll find at Berkeley that everyone has different abilities when it comes to managing courseload. I'd say don't be afraid of people saying you won't be able to handle certain combinations of classes because they don't know how you work or what you're capable of. If it becomes too difficult and you already feel yourself struggling in the first few weeks, you can always drop a class, but I'd say don't be afraid to test yourself. You only get to take classes at the college level once in your life.

was in 61c with garcia and 126 last semester; seemed like a fair amount of people in my 126 class were also taking 61c and 170, so this is probably not an uncommon combination

I'd say that 126 problem sets, while they don't look super long, take a lot of thinking; expect to go to office hours.

61c really depends on how caught up you are with the material.

It pretty much depends on what you know, your workload tolerance, and what kind of grade you're looking for. 170 isn't too bad imo. It's very much like 70. 61c also isn't too bad. It's sort of like 61b. I'm not too sure on 126/127, but I'd imagine that if you have a light schedule and a keen eye for math, you'd be fine. For reference, I'm taking 61c, 170, and another tech right now, and it's pretty manageable. Also, I wouldn't come close to classifying myself as a genius. 

Personally, I believe in being fearless and testing your own limits. So if you think you can manage that courseload, why not? What's the worse thing that could happen? Failing isn't the end of the world.
A lot of people here may discourage you, but only you know your limits. I'd say go for it, but be prepared to drop something if it comes to it.

I did 126+61c+170 + heavy extracurriculars my sophmore spring

it will either destroy ur gpa or you really won't have the time to absorb/enjoy the material as you'll be optimizing grades not understanding (both cases applied to me lol)

regret not taking my time with 126 material, missed out on a lot of cool stuff that I might've wanted to pursue further

unless u know ur like 99th percentile ofc

history.content:
I’m trying to graduate in 3 years, and I’m considering the following:

1. 61c,
2. 126 or 127
3. 170

I’ve met all the prerequisites, but I’m not too sure if this course load is manageable. Any recommendations are appreciated.
history.subject: Fall Schedule as a Sophomore
